If we want to continue pursuing the American experiment, fundamentally, every American today should be working to ensure that every ballot can be cast safely, that it will be counted fairly, and that the outcome of our elections will reflect the true will of the people.
There are no guarantees that our nation will persist as the kind of representative democracy our founders envisioned 250 years ago.

We rightly celebrate the victory of democracy over violence last year.

Despite the siege of the Capitol, the insurrection, orchestrated by some at our government’s highest levels, failed at the end of the day, Congress completed its constitutional duties and two weeks later we witnessed a peaceful transition of power to a new administration.

From escaping  the House Gallery as a violent crowd tried to break through the chamber doors to defiantly returning later that evening to fulfill our job and certify the count of electoral ballots, the day for me represented the steely resilience of our democratic institutions.

They failed.

The coup attempt on January 6th was a warning for what’s to come if we don’t act. The work to prevent the next coup begins now.

That requires abolishing fundamentally antidemocratic elements of our system like the Senate filibuster and the electoral college, and it requires major investments in childcare, education, health and climate like the Build Back Better Act.
But it also requires reforming our institutions so that they are once again responsive to the core demands of our constituents.

To stop the next coup, we must reinvigorate the democratic experience. That requires, at a minimum, passing the John Lewis Voting Rights Act and strengthening election laws around the country to prevent the next coup.
"A democracy is more than a form of government; it is primarily a mode of associated living, of conjoint communicated experience," John Dewey once said.
Borrowing from demagogues around the world, authoritarians like Donald Trump filled the void, offering false promises while scapegoating immigrants, and religious and racial minorities.
Trust in our government’s ability to tackle the biggest problems we face—from healthcare to climate to food insecurity—has cratered as a result.

Inequality has skyrocketed, as has the cost of basics like healthcare and education, while the average American’s wages have not kept pace. Self-interested elites have prioritized profit and greed over the common good.

But the causes of the attempts to overturn our democracy run much deeper than Donald Trump. For decades, our institutions have been failing to meet the needs of the people they are tasked to represent.

If that’s not enough, they are stripping power from nonpartisan election officials and rewriting state laws to seize partisan control over election certification. The next coup is not only possible; it has already begun.
In fact, as we speak, Donald Trump’s allies in statehouses across the country are seeking to erect barriers to voting—largely affecting low-income people, people of color, and seniors.
I know personally what happens when a government fails, civil strife takes hold, and people are displaced. And I know that coup attempts are rarely one-time affairs.

Every day, I am thankful for those in Congress and in state election offices throughout the country who stood fast to uphold the will of the people, even in the face of imminent danger.

We must remain strong to bring the perpetrators of these crimes to justice and take action to ensure this never happens again. The threat to American democracy is not past but ever present, and we must defend the foundation of our nation.

Today marks the one-year anniversary of one of the greatest tragedies and threats our nation has seen. I want to extend my sincerest thanks to the Capitol Police, who put their lives on the line to protect those of us working at the Capitol that day and our very democracy.

At 12 noon I will join Senate colleagues in observing a moment of silence to mark one year since the January 6 insurrection. Soon after I will deliver a floor speech about the attack, investigation, & ongoing efforts to protect & strengthen our democracy. Tune in live on @cspan.

Today marks one year since the devastating insurrection at our Capitol. We must not back down in our mission to deliver justice and uncover the truth about what took place on January 6th. We cannot allow what happened that day to be swept under the rug.

We all must come together: Democrats, Republicans, Independents & recommit to the fight of the civil rights giants who came before, including my friend John Lewis, working harder than ever to protect the right to vote. Our democracy & country depend on it. https://www.cnn.com/2022/01/05/opinions/january-6-anniversary-voting-rights-allred/index.html

But in that moment, I felt a strong determination to not let the insurrectionists win and to not let them stop our democratic process and erase the will of the American people. And we did so that night. A strong bipartisan vote certifying the results.

Nearly everyone in that room, Republicans and Democrats alike, were shocked. I saw the looks on some of my colleagues' faces who now say the 6th wasn’t dangerous, wasn’t an insurrection. They are not telling the truth. I was with them, I saw and heard their shock and horror too.

I did multiple interviews from that room, including the @dallasnews article above. The rioters were still in the Capitol, but I was determined to go back to the floor as soon as possible to certify the election. You can see me here with @RepPeteAguilar and @RepJeffries. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIbwKMJXsAEKMl6.jpg

In the secured room I still did not feel we were safe, so I took apart a stanchion and prepared to use it to defend the room if it too came under attack. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIbwFegXMAMGgXT.jpg

As we evacuated, I saw the Parliamentarians carrying some of the priceless heirlooms from the Speaker’s rostrum, the oldest things the House still has dating back to our earliest days. I asked why, and he said to make sure they weren’t lost to history.

Eventually the call came to evacuate. As I left I turned & saw glass flying from the main door as rioters tried to break in. The officers stayed behind, guns drawn & pointed. They saved my life. I would not have met my son Cameron if not for their bravery. https://twitter.com/RepColinAllred/status/1346916705130459140?s=20 QT @RepColinAllred I was evacuated from the House floor and am currently safe.

We could hear banging on the doors that the President walks through to give the State of the Union. The doors were barricaded with furniture usually used to hold legislative papers. The officers in the chamber pulled their guns and told us to stay away from the doors.

I texted my pregnant wife at home with our two year-old, “Whatever happens, I love you.” The ornamental doors were closed and locked. Alarms started blaring. I will never forget that alarm sound. In my mind, I was preparing to make a last stand. https://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/2021/01/06/whatever-happens-i-love-you-dallas-rep-colin-allred-recalls-chaotic-scene-as-mob-breached-the-capitol/

I took off my suit jacket and prepared to fight. Several of my colleagues joined me in taking off their jackets. You can see me helping @RepJeffries with his mask here. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIbvGduWQAkWcVr.jpg

We again tried to continue the debate, now with @RepMcGovern presiding. But soon thereafter, the proceedings were again interrupted and we were told that the mob had breached the Capitol, that tear gas had been deployed in the rotunda, and to grab the gas masks under our seats.

An announcement was made that the Capitol was under attack, but that we were safe and should continue the proceedings. Soon thereafter, security personnel swept into the Chamber and grabbed our top leadership and hurried them out.

During the debate, I began receiving alarmed texts from friends, family and staff asking where I was. I responded that I was on the House floor, which to me meant that I was in one of the safest places in the world.

As the results for Alabama and Alaska were certified and accepted, I braced to see what would happen when Arizona was called. Paul Gosar rose to object. His objection was seconded by Ted Cruz and many on the Republican side cheered. I felt something very dark was beginning.

As a member of the Democratic leadership team, I took my place on the House floor near @RepCheri, @RepBarbaraLee, @RepJeffries, @RepSeanMaloney, @RepPeteAguilar and @RepMondaire. The Vice President and the Senate entered the House for the Joint Session to begin.

When I got into the office I saw a New Year’s card from @RepCicilline on my desk with a quote from John Lewis. I took a picture of it to remind myself to stay hopeful throughout the day. Mr. Lewis would have been proud of his state’s election the night before. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIbu1mKXIAIIniB.jpg

A year ago I woke up early, anxious and excited for a long but historic day. I was encouraged by the election in Georgia the night before, w/ the first Jewish and Black Senator ever elected to represent the state, and I was ready to certify the results of a historic election. ⬇️

I’m a mom of four kids. I want them to have the same freedoms and protections, the same opportunities and say in their government that we have had. So today, as we commemorate and reflect, it’s their future that I’m thinking about most.

Today, as we remember what happened, our focus should be on what we can and need to do to ensure an attack like that never happens again. It’s our duty now to do everything in our power to safeguard our American values and freedoms.
January 6 marked a dark day in our democracy. But it does not and will not define us.

I could have never imagined living up to that oath would one day mean protecting our democracy from fellow Americans or a former president who sought to undermine our elections in an attempt to stay in power.

When I repeated those words, the images of the Nazis my grandfather fought during World War II or the armies of the Soviet Union I saw growing up during the Cold War were the ones that populated my mind.
That oath bestows the responsibility to support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign or domestic.

I’ve taken that oath many times. The first when I was 18 years old entering the US Naval Academy, excited and proud to serve our nation. Since then, I’ve taken it throughout my Naval career, at the US Attorney’s Office, and, now, as your Congresswoman.

Today, I want to share some reflections I have on the one year anniversary of that attack.

On that day, and in the year after it, my mind turned to two things: my family and my oath to the Constitution.

On January 6, 2021, I stood in the House Gallery as an angry mob, sent by the President of the United States, stormed the Capitol building with the intention of preventing Congress from carrying out the will of the people and certifying our election.
Read my full statement: https://www.menendez.senate.gov/newsroom/press/menendez-statement-on-first-anniversary-of-the-january-6th-insurrection

Last year’s insurrection must serve as a moment of national reckoning. During this sad anniversary we must reaffirm our commitment to doing everything necessary to ensure our Republic prevails, stronger and more resilient than ever before.
Since then, so-called leaders like Trump have sought to further undermine our constitution and democratic process by lying about the 2020 election and has encouraging his supporters to do the same.

It prevailed because of heroes like New Jersey native Brian Sicknick, and his fellow Capitol police officer Eugene Goodman, who fought valiantly to protect our elected leaders, and our democracy. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIb20kWXsAEDnkk.jpg
That day, the foundation of our constitutional order was severely eroded but democracy prevailed and power was transferred peacefully on Jan. 21. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIb2on2XMAMBvIh.jpg
One year ago today, the world watched in horror as our sacred temple of democracy, the U.S. Capitol building, was besieged by fellow Americans. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIb2iQRX0AQeXya.jpg

A year on, we can’t turn a blind eye to the instances of violent domestic extremism that continue to bubble up in our country.
We saw federal law enforcement and National Guardsmen clear and secure the building. At the end of the day, there was law and law enforcement — and no one is above that law.
As dark as this violent assault on our democracy was, we also witnessed true heroism on that awful day. We saw Capitol Police officers risk everything to divert the mob and save lives.

What took place on this day was domestic terrorism — a violent attempt, rooted in a lie, to overturn the will of the majority of the American people, and one of the most egregious acts of domestic violent extremism we’ve ever seen on our shores.

The one moment that day when I choked up was when I realized how grateful I felt that my grandparents, including veterans of the Second World War, weren’t alive to see what was happening to our Capitol.

As the day unfolded, I thought of all the time I spent working overseas in countries where people are desperate for a shot at the kind of government we have here: democracy & self-determination. How many of our ancestors braved the journey to the U.S. because of these ideals?

I was in the tunnels under the Capitol when I heard the gunshot that killed one of the rioters. I ran to my office to barricade myself in with another member who couldn’t get to his own, & spent the rest of the day on the phone with Chairman Milley & the Secretary of the Army.
It was an attack that didn’t emanate abroad — instead, it was mobilized here at home, and it was carried out by a misguided group of our fellow Americans, some of whom came from Michigan.
It’s hard to believe that it’s been a year since a day that is so deeply seared into our collective memory. One year ago today, a violent mob laid siege to the very symbol of American democracy.

The window in my office is directly across from the Capitol. So, I watched the mob run up the Capitol steps. I saw the buses that had brought the marauding insurrectionists there. I saw the police officers.

It was a very, very eerie feeling. We were stunned, alarmed, and afraid.

At the time, we thought the Capitol might be the safest place to go. But, only Members were allowed in because of COVID precautions.

I told the two staffers with me that day, “I’m not leaving without you.” So, we hunkered down. We bolted and barricaded the door. And we waited.

On #January6th, I was in my office in Rayburn when we heard the news that insurrectionists had breached one of the buildings in the Capitol complex.

My staff and I turned to each other and started thinking frantically about what to do — what was our plan? [THREAD]

10) Now we all need to step up to do our patriotic duty–to tell the truth, to demand accountability, and to foster change–to preserve America in this dangerous time.
9) I am eternally grateful to the Capitol Police, Metro Police Department, National Guardsmen and all other first responders who served our institution bravely and kept us safe on that day.
8) American democracy does not exist on its own. It has always relied on brave, patriotic, truth-telling volunteers to fight for its preservation and success.
7) If those who promoted the lie that the election was stolen are not held accountable, including the former President and his associates who continue to flaunt the law, this will happen again.
6) While many people, including many of my colleagues here in Congress, want to move on, history has shown us that there can be no reconciliation without accountability.
5) In state legislatures across the country, many Republicans are working to install insurrectionist election officials to overturn results they don’t like at the local level.

4) Since that fateful day, I am dismayed by how little has changed. Only a few brave Republicans remain willing to speak the truth in public that they all know in private. That is why the likelihood of another 1/6 happening in the future is stronger today than it was a year ago.

3) While physically this was an assault on Congress, principally it was an assault on the American ppl. Changing election results by denying the truth & strong-arming dem. institutions is the stuff of totalitarianism, of places like Russia & China & Myanmar, of dictators.

2) Five people died as a result of that day, including four brave police officers. Today, many of our first responders, my colleagues, Capitol Hill staffers, and other public servants, are still dealing with trauma from the attack.

I love that the Capitol has this ornate flourish but still has paintings of moon landers and astronauts (in renaissance-esque style) 9/16 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE_0TXMAUzq2u.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE_6XWYAEaJel.jpg

My favorite room is the Rotunda. I believe it is the most beautiful room in the most beautiful building in America. Over the course of 3 yrs in Congress, I’ve taken hundreds of photos of this room and it never loses its magic. 8/16 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE-4EWYAU_CTp.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE--GWUAEN7Tl.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE--eWQAkCCRf.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE_C5XIAEo51Z.jpg
You can see parts of the mural painting that you can’t see from below.  7/16 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE-dUXIAUIa1e.jpg
From here you can see the mural intimately and feel it’s grandeur under the Capitol dome.  6/16 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE96XXoAUsvuP.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE969XMAIXYsP.jpg

Back inside the Capitol, there is a viewing platform directly below the ceiling mural that is stunning but also not for those with fear of heights as it is high above the rotunda floor. 5/16 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE9buXwAE-X-a.jpg
Getting up to the top is a bit crazy. This isn’t open to the public but my office made the trek. 4/16 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE8rnWQAIUgv7.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE8sPXsAEaCC3.jpg
On the other side you can look down at the Supreme Court (left) and Library of Congress (right) 3/16 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE8GVWYAUDH2R.jpg

The view of DC from the top of the Capitol dome can’t be beat as you stare out across the national mall. 2/16 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE38OXwAAmO1r.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE39CXwAAfmTr.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FIdE39KWUAI6Rd5.jpg

I believe in this country, and most importantly, I believe in the ideals upon which it was founded. That the right to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness are unalienable. We all share that in common. Let us start there.

While the shining light on the hill might have dimmed a little, I have no doubt that it will burn even more brightly as we reflect, as history bends toward justice, and as we do the hard work of reminding our family, friends, and neighbors of the values we share.

January 6, 2021, is a date that will most assuredly go down in infamy. It’s a black mark on our still young democratic experiment and not something any of us should take lightly.
